context: The sampling and analytical methods employed for the chamber test were also utilized for this in-vehicle test. Frequency of occurrence The AFs emitted 84 compounds, and all 26 household products emitted at least one compound. Nevertheless, Table 1 presents the frequency of occurrence for the 50 analytes that satisfied the cut-off point for the reporting compounds, as described above. Eleven analytes occurred at a frequency of more than 50%: toluene (100%), bis(trimethylsilyl)acetylene (96%), benzene (92%), hexamethylcyclotrisiloxane (81%), pentadecane (81%), ethanol (65%), ethyl benzene (62%), limonene (58%), m,p-xylene (57%), and tetramethylsilane (50%). Among these 11 compounds, five compounds (toluene, benzene, ethyl benzene, and m,p-xylene) are listed as either a toxic air contaminant, a hazardous air pollutant, or as being on California′s Proposition 65 List (OEHHA, 2003). The United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) suggested the guidelines of 200, 1, 100, and 100 parts per million (ppm) for toluene, benzene, ethyl benzene, and xylene, respectively (OSHA, 1998). These toxic or hazardous compounds are prevalent in households or public buildings and can be caused by a variety of sources (Tucker, 2000; Edwards et al., 2005; Zuraimi et al., 2006).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylbenzene and tetramethylsilane are both mentioned as compounds detected in a study of air quality, specifically in relation to household products and their emissions. Ethylbenzene is noted for its frequency of occurrence among hazardous air pollutants, while tetramethylsilane is included in the list of compounds analyzed. However, there is no direct interaction or functional relationship discussed between the two compounds, as they are simply part of a broader analysis of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the environment.
